source.5230359d:
list_lat = []
list_lon = []

for i in range(dest.shape[0]):
    list_lat.append(dest.loc[i,'LATLON'][0])
    list_lon.append(dest.loc[i,'LATLON'][1])

dest['LATITUDE']=list_lat
dest['LONGITUDE']=list_lon
dest=dest.drop(['LATLON'],axis=1)
dest
source.ba2d228e:
#https://www.python-graph-gallery.com/313-bubble-map-with-folium
import folium

# Make an empty map
m = folium.Map(location=[36.815265823160814, -98.25070610546217], tiles="OpenStreetMap", zoom_start=5)

# add marker one by one on the map
for i in range(0,len(dest)):
   folium.Circle(
      location=[dest.iloc[i]['LATITUDE'], dest.iloc[i]['LONGITUDE']],
      popup=dest.iloc[i]['DEST'],
      radius=float(dest.iloc[i]['FlIGHT COUNT'])*5,
      color='blue',
      fill=True,
      fill_color='blue'
   ).add_to(m)

# Show the map again
m

df1

source.9e12700c: Now we know there are 6 categorical features.
source.87db170c:
This graph below shows short-distance airlines are often used in terms of flight number.

OGG:Kahului(Hawaii)
HNL:Honolulu(Hawaii)
JFK:John F Kennedy(New York)
LAX:Los Angeles International Airport(LA)
LAS:Las Vegas McCarran International Airport(Las Vegas)
LGA:La Guardia Airport(New York)
ORD:O'Hare International Airport(Chicago)
SFO:San Francisco International Airport(San Francisco)
source.0937282e: I think we can say, large company has long-distance flight(2000 miles above) and South West earns money from short-distant fights
source.2d008652:
# Closing Word How was your flight?
I hope you find something new with this notebook.
I will update this notebook sometimes.
We all miss travel very much.
I hope that the corona will end and we can travel around the world again in the near future.
I don't want to spend the night at the airport again, though.
source.79835c50: There are unique 353 airports and many lines uses Atlanta(ATL) airport.
source.5df0ad48:
It is not easy to reconginize some airline company with Carrier Code.
Let's change company code
source.30f82182:
Oh, it is not.

People use Alaska airline to go to San Francisco from Los Angels??

It must be mistake...Let's check the price on [internet](https://www.alaskaair.com/en/flights-from-los-angeles-to-san-francisco)!
source.abedb627:
Let's see the histogram of distance
We can see there are many short-distance flights which makes sence.
I guess Low-cost carriers such as South West turn around immediately after landing, so you can imagine that there are more takeoffs and landings on short-haul
flights.Low-cost carriers turn around immediately after landing, so you can imagine that there are more takeoffs and landings on short-haul flights.
source.182e0bd4:
It seems Delta Air Lines seems to account for 60% of the total.

Following explanation is from [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delta_Air_Lines) Now it makes sense.
--Wikipedia--
Delta Air Lines, Inc., typically referred to as Delta, is one of the major airlines of the United States and a legacy carrier. It is **headquartered in Atlanta**,
Georgia.The airline, along with its subsidiaries and regional affiliates, including Delta Connection, operates over 5,400 flights daily and serves 325 destinations
in 52 countries on six continents. Delta is a founding member of the SkyTeam airline alliance.

Delta has nine hubs, with Atlanta being its largest in terms of total passengers and number of departures.It is ranked second among the world's largest
airlines by number of scheduled passengers carried, revenue passenger-kilometers flown, and fleet size. It is ranked 69th on the Fortune 500.The company
slogan is "Keep Climbing."
source.82a32de6:
Let's see how many airlines there are and each percentage.There are 17 unique careeres.
It seems that Southwest accounts for 19% of the total.
Southwest is one of the biggest lowcost carrer in the U.S., so it makes sence.
source.ac08b5d7: It is cheaper than I expected...Good. It makes sense.
source.c0907172:
So, which airline do people take to go to San Francisco from Los Angels?
There 2 cities are very close, so it must be low-cost carrier.

source.8d5832df:
Definition of the table * 'DAY_OF_MONTH': Day of the month.
* 'DAY_OF_WEEK': Day of the week.
* 'OP_UNIQUE_CARRIER': Unique transport code.
* 'OP_CARRIER_AIRLINE_ID': Unique aviation operator code.
* 'OP_CARRIER': IATA code of the operator.
* 'TAIL_NUM': Tail number.
* 'OP_CARRIER_FL_NUM': Flight number.
* 'ORIGIN_AIRPORT_ID': Origin airport ID.
* 'ORIGIN_AIRPORT_SEQ_ID': Origin airport ID - SEQ.
* 'ORIGIN': Airport of Origin.
* 'DEST_AIRPORT_ID': ID of the destination airport.
* 'DEST_AIRPORT_SEQ_ID': Destination airport ID - SEQ.
* 'DEST': Destination airport.
* 'DEP_TIME': Flight departure time.
* 'DEP_DEL15': Departure delay indicator
* 'DEP_TIME_BLK': block of time (hour) where the match has been postponed.
* 'ARR_TIME': Flight arrival time.
* 'ARR_DEL15': Arrival delay indicator.
* 'CANCELLED': Flight cancellation indicator.
* 'DIVERTED': Indicator if the flight has been diverted.
* 'DISTANCE': Distance between airports.

source.a12fd1df:
# Introduction Many people are missing travel and flight. Covid changes everything.
I have slept 1 night on seat in U.S. Airport when I was young.
It was really painful at that time. However,it is good memory now.

Today, I would like to bring you to some stories regarding travel with dataset "[January Flight Delay Prediction](https://www.kaggle.com/divyansh22/flight-delay-prediction)".
This data is US Flight Data for the month of Jan 2019 and Jan 2020.

Here's a question for you.Here's a question for you.

Where is the busiest airport in the United States?

JFK(New York)? LAX(Los Angeles)?

Actually, neither.

You will find out where it is with some visuals on this notebook.

Have a good flight!!
source.fd273dfd:
# Dataset This file contains all the flights starting from 1st January 2019 till 31st January 2019. There are around 400,000 rows
in this file and 21 feature columns indicating the features of the flight including information about origin airport,
destination airport, airplane information, departure time and arrival time.
